main.name: Yuxi (Jaden) Long
main.description: Every finite field has prime power order
main.bio:
I am an undergraduate student at Duke University working on computational biology. My current research focuses on protein and drug design, but I also have experience in bioinformatics and deep learning based image analysis through previous research projects.

My English name is Jaden, and my Chinese name is 龙玉玺 (a reasonably approximate pronouncation is Lone-You Shee).

resume.skillmessage: Here you can create a short write-up of your skills to show off to employers

education.degree: Double Major in Mathematics and Computer Science, Minor in Biology
education.description: Relevant courses: Algebraic Topology I, Representation Theory, Computational Biology, Molecular Assembly and Computation, Principles of Immunology, Cell Biology, Real Analysis I, Topology, Algebraic Structures I, Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos, Complex Analysis, Combinatorics, Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Introduction to Computational Genomics, Neurosymbolic Machine Learning, Computer Vision

work.title: Undergraduate Researcher
work.description: • (In progress) Developing an persistent homology algorithm model the positive and negative design energy spaces to faciliate design of targeted drugs.

work.title: Computational Biology Summer Intern
work.description:
• Developed the first ever interpretable multiple instance learning algorithm for predicting progression after chemotherapy for patients with neuroblastoma, a cancer diagnosed in about 1,000 children yearly.
  • Shadowed Dr.Shakeel Modak, one of the leading neuroblastoma oncologists in the United States. Observed his patient visits, surgery procedures, learned about medical technology development, and learned about the daily routines of a physician-scientist.

work.title: Undergraduate Researcher
work.description:
• Independently developed a pipeline that identifies large plasmid inserts using a de Bruijn graph assembled from short read sequencing data. Identified the exact location of a 7,258 bp plasmid and confirmed the expression of the sick gene during Drosophila dorsal closure.
  • Given sequencing data from Illumina MiSeq and Oxford Nanopore, researched and executed a novel hybrid assembly algorithm (WENGAN) to identify the exact sequence of a 5,400 bp transposable element of interest. Manuscript from this project is pending publication.
  • Using GATK, performed variant calling on MiSeq sequencing data and screened out 75 EMS-induced lethal mutations that could have led to a deficiency in the gene Df(2R)ES1 in the Drosophila dorsal closure process.

work.title: Undergraduate Researcher
work.description:
• Using R, Python and a suite of bioinformatics tools, analyzed the relative proportion of hepatocytes from two different humans in 101 humanized mice using the relative abundance of known alleles to analyze the drug reactivity of different SNPs.
  • Used hisat2 and DESeq2 to identify differentially expressed genes in a set of six mice with half of them treated with a certain drug and the other half as control.

work.company: Bass Connections: Creating Artificial Worlds with AI to Improve Energy Access Data
work.title: Data Scientist
work.description:
• Generated synthetic overhead imagery for energy infrastructure with a generative adversarial network (GP-GAN). Improved the within domain precision of our deep learning object detection model by 14.5% and cross domain precision by 96.7% by combining real wind turbine and synthetic imageries.
  • Developed scripts to test synthetic imageries across all pairs of domains autonomously. Developed scripts that implemented other deep-learning based domain adaptation techniques as comparison, including CycleGAN, DM-ADA, and CyCADA.
  • My colleague and I have presented this work at the 2022 NeurIPS Climate Change AI workshop as a poster presentation.

extracurricular.title: President, Co-Founder
extracurricular.description:
• Founded and led InTranscription@Duke, the highest quality biotechnology club at Duke. This club gathered 107 general members in the first six months, with 22 active members working on a diverse array of projects weekly.
  • Built up an executive board of 7 students passionate about my mission for the club.
  • Established partnership with three well-respected organizations at Duke and connected their resources to us.
  • Organized and hosted five events, with event attendees representing 10 different affiliations.
  • Designed the logo of InT@Duke with Inkscape. Programmed the website of InT@Duke with React and published to intduke.com using Vercel.

extracurricular.title: Electrical Engineer
extracurricular.description:
• Designed a wiring harness for a vehicle that competed in Formula SAE (FSAE) with 100 connections using RapidHarness and Autodesk CAD Electrical.
  • Programmed the MoTeC M130 Engine Control Unit (ECU) and allowed for automatic shutdown of the engine after sensor disconnection.
  • Performed meticulous labeling, crimping, and heat shrinking to produce a finished wiring.

projects.description:
• Worked with a biophysics visiting scholar Daniel Haertter to design a set of softwares that track the geometry of hundreds of cells across thousands of frames in a fluorescence microscopy movie.
  • Developed bio-image-unet, a neural network that semantically segments cell boundaries in microscopy images. Implemented a custom data loader, an augmentation pipeline, an uncommon network structure known as Siamese U-Net with PyTorch, and 5 different loss functions, which combined to close previously visible holes in the final segmentation. A sample of some recent results: video 1, video 2. The Siamese U-Net was later used in a separate project on sarcomere analysis by Daniel, due to its robust performance.
  • Devised a custom algorithm to evaluate cell tracking quality, and evaluated different tracking algorithms with it. Planning to publish our software to PyPI so that developmental biologists around the world can install and analyze their microscopy data with our software. A current version of the package and GUI are published on TestPyPI.

projects.company: An Interactive Animation of Persistent Homology in Biomolecules
projects.description:
• Designed and implemented the world's first interactive visualization of persistent homology in the context of biomolecules. This animation only requires a browser and is publicly available on https://www.intduke.com/ph.
  • This animation premiered at InT@UCLA Biohackathon 2023, and had received accolades from computer scientists and biochemists alike for its ability to visually explain the concept of persistent homology and enlighten its relevance to biochemistry. This animation received third place in the competition.

projects.company: Monte-Carlo Tree Search for Protein Design
projects.description:
• Implemented a Monte-Carlo tree search (MCTS) algorithm along with a neural network for conformational energy prediction that explores the protein design space. Interfaced with the OSPREY protein design software to evaluate the energy of a protein conformation.
  • Sadly, this project was discontinued in favor of other projects, due to the lack of time and lack of promising results.

projects.company: Hoo-Ray: A distributed execution engine for Haskell
projects.description:
• Jointly designed and implemented an automatic parallelization engine for Haskell which we named Hoo-Ray. Hoo-Ray exploits the purity of Haskell functions and statically analyzes its functional dependencies. Hoo-Ray then uses a greedy scheduler to execute the program in parallel on a cluster of computers.
  • We have met with and received feedback from the creator of Haskell, Simon Peyton-Jones. He expressed his interest in our work and gave ideas for future directions.
  • This work has been submitted to the 2023 ACM SIGPLAN ICFP Haskell Symposium.

random.description:
• I love Latin literature. I have taken a Latin paleography class in my freshman year, which examines the handwritings of the Latin writers (mostly monks copying the Bible).
  • When one of the most prominent math educators, 3Blue1Brown, visited Duke campus for a talk in March of 2023, I coordinated his visit and led him around Duke campus. He inspired my persistent homology animation.
  • I am a classical guitar player.
  • At Duke, I have performed solo, chamber music, and in a Chinese music ensemble.
  • I was elected and still am a forum administrator on the largest Chinese guitar forum, GuitarChina.
  • I have published 8 transcriptions on MuseScore, a sheet music sharing platform. They have received more than 15,000 views in total.
  • I record my playing and upload them to YouTube and Bilibili, a Chinese video sharing platform. My channels have received more than 30,000 views in total.
  • In 2020, I have gotten third place in the high school track of Columbus State University Guitar Symposium and Competition among high school students aspiring to play professionally.
